from_pandas_ephemeral(engine, df, ...)

Instantiate a new DataFrame based on the content of a Pandas DataFrame.

from_pandas_store_table(engine, df, ...[, ...])

Instantiate a new DataFrame based on the content of a Pandas DataFrame.
bach.from_pandas.from_pandas(engine: sqlalchemy.engine.base.Engine, df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, convert_objects: bool, name: str, materialization: str, if_exists: str = 'fail') → bach.dataframe.DataFrame[source]¶

See DataFrame.from_pandas() for docstring.

bach.from_pandas.from_pandas_ephemeral(engine: sqlalchemy.engine.base.Engine, df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, convert_objects: bool, name: str) → bach.dataframe.DataFrame[source]¶

Instantiate a new DataFrame based on the content of a Pandas DataFrame. The data will be represented using a select * from values() query.

Warning: This method is only suited for small quantities of data. For anything over a dozen kilobytes of data it is recommended to store the data in a table in the database, e.g. by using the from_pd_store_table() function.

Supported dtypes are ‘int64’, ‘float64’, ‘string’, ‘datetime64[ns]’, ‘bool’

Parameters

  • engine – db connection

  • df – Pandas DataFrame to instantiate as DataFrame

  • convert_objects – If True, columns of type ‘object’ are converted to ‘string’ using the pd.convert_dtypes() method where possible.

bach.from_pandas.from_pandas_store_table(engine: sqlalchemy.engine.base.Engine, df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, convert_objects: bool, table_name: str, if_exists: str = 'fail') → bach.dataframe.DataFrame[source]¶

Instantiate a new DataFrame based on the content of a Pandas DataFrame. This will first write the data to a database table using pandas’ df.to_sql() method. Supported dtypes are ‘int64’, ‘float64’, ‘string’, ‘datetime64[ns]’, ‘bool’

Parameters

  • engine – db connection

  • df – Pandas DataFrame to instantiate as DataFrame

  • convert_objects – If True, columns of type ‘object’ are converted to ‘string’ using the pd.convert_dtypes() method where possible.

  • table_name – name of the sql table the Pandas DataFrame will be written to

  • if_exists – {‘fail’, ‘replace’, ‘append’}, default ‘fail’ How to behave if the table already exists: * fail: Raise a ValueError. * replace: Drop the table before inserting new values. * append: Insert new values to the existing table.
